availability.p: All research and writing of Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition annotations was undertaken by project staff, volunteers, and interns. Each record contains citations to relevant primary and secondary source material. All annotations are copyright Kentucky Historical Society, and should be referenced as such in any published work.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition

person.persName: Lewis Dudley Wilson (Montgomery County, Kentucky, farmer)

body.p: Montgomery County, Kentucky, farmer. Kentucky native. Son of Abraham Wilson and Nancy Tapp Wilson Jeffries. Married to Eliza Tipton Wilson. Father of Nancy E. Wilson Easton and Luther M. Wilson. Farmer in Montgomery County, Kentucky, in 1850. Owned three enslaved persons in Montgomery County in 1850. Farmer in Montgomery County in 1860. Owned six enslaved persons in Montgomery County in 1860.

ab.bibl:
Seventh Manuscript Census of the United States (1850), Population Schedules, Kentucky, Montgomery County, District 2, p. 69B.
Seventh Manuscript Census of the United States (1850), Slave Schedules, Kentucky, Montgomery County, District 2, p. 53.
Eighth Manuscript Census of the United States (1860), Population Schedules, Kentucky, Montgomery County, p. 199.
Eighth Manuscript Census of the United States (1860), Slave Schedules, Kentucky, Montgomery County, p. 88A.
Ninth Manuscript Census of the United States (1870), Population Schedules, Kentucky, Montgomery County, Mt. Sterling, p. 308A.
Kentucky Birth, Marriage and Death Records (1852-1910), KDLA, Frankfort, KY, Roll 994039, Montgomery County Marriages.
Kentucky Death Certificates, 1911-1965, Kentucky Office of Vital Statistics, KDLA, Frankfort, KY, File 22837.
John Marshall Prewitt, "The Tapp, Wilson, and Prewitt Families of Montgomery County," Kentucky Ancestors, vol. 40, no. 2 (Winter 2004): p. 95-96.
"Lewis Dudley Wilson (1816-1894)," Find A Grave, Memorial 84926985, accessed October 11, 2023, http://www.findagrave.com/memorial/84926985.
